Overview of the role of pesticides 
in bee decline 
By 
the end of this lecture, you should be able to 
Recognize that bees are exposed to dozens of pesticides 
Compare/contrast 
lethal and sublethal effects of pesticides 
Articulate 
one way sublethal effects could have a detrimental 
impact on honey bees 
Explain 
how neonicotinoids are different from other insecticides 
Understand 
why synergistic effects between different pesticides, 
including fungicides, are relevant to bee health

Main stressors of bees 
Especially novel pests and 
pathogens 
Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens 
Climate Change 
Habitat Change 
(loss and 
fragmentation) 
Management 
Practices 
Agrochemicals 
Insecticides 
Fungicides 
Herbicides 
• 
Range distribution 
• 
Phenological 
mismatch 
• 
Extreme events 
Stress of transport and poor 
Low diversity 
management 
(or lack of) resources 
by beekeepers 
and nest sites

The 
cumulative effect of repeated exposure to 
sublethal doses of pesticides in a social insect 
species is not taken into account

Yet we know that subtle but cumulative effects of 
some insecticides can be detrimental to social bees: 
example of the effect of imidacloprid in 
Bombus 
terrestris 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U2GBYG5RwEI&ab_channel=ScienceMagazine

The 
sublethal effects of herbicides and fungicides 
on bees is 
typically not taken account when approval of a pesticide is granted

Neonics 
present in the groundwater and soil can be uptaken 
by plants the next year, thus bees can be exposed to 
a single neonic application for many years

Worldwide contamination of honey by neonicotinoids. 
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28983052/ 
A 2017 study found 75% of honey samples from around the world contained at 
least 1 neonicotinoid, even on remote islands such as Curacao and Tahiti

And 
honey bees are not the only species impacted 
 
 
 
 
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14420 
(published 2015)

A summary of worrisome features of 
neonicotinoid pesticides 
as far as bees are concerned: 
• 
High toxicity (10,000 x more toxic than DDT) 
• 
Water soluble so they can accumulate in ground and surface 
water 
• 
Can be taken up by root systems of non
-
target plants 
• 
Are expressed in all plant tissues 
• 
Long term persistence (=years) 
• 
Sublethal effects (disrupted orientation, reduced 
reproduction, etc.) 
• 
To  this  day 
Bayer and Syngenta maintain that their 
insecticides are entirely benign to bees 
and other beneficial 
insects 
For more information: 
http://www.xerces.org/neonicotinoids
-
and
-
bees/

In 2013, the EU banned 3 Neonicotinoids 
(clothianidin, imidacloprid, thiamethoxam)
on flowering crops (meaning NOT cereals)

The 2013 ban 
enacted by the 
EU did not result 
in positive effects 
for bees. WHY? 
-
Share your ideas with your neighbors 
(DO NOT google it!) 
-
Be ready to share with the whole classroom 
using 
PollEverywhere 
3 min

The 2013 ban was 
not 
enough! 
Cereal seeds 
coated with 
neonicotinoids 
continued being 
used 
Those 
neonicotinoids 
leached into 
soil and 
groundwater 
thus could be 
uptaken 
by wild plants

In 2018, the EU 
agreed to renew 
and EXTEND the ban 
to 
all outdoor 
uses 
of  clothianidin, 
imidacloprid, 
thiamethoxam

Critics argued that it was 
not 
enough because of 
a loophole used by many EU member states 
Example: 
Beet farmers 
In Northern France 
Farmers could still apply to their national government for a 
derogation. They had to argue that it was an emergency use, and 
that no suitable alternative method of pest control was available.

On January 2023, the EU closed that loophole, 
and 
no more emergency uses 
can be allowed
